Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Lateral Heterojunctions: Fabrication & Characteristics of a Novel Concept in 2D Materials Electronics
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-technical Description: Two-dimensional materials such as graphene and molybdenum disulfide have attracted considerable attention because they may offer a facile way of fabricating electronic devices at the ultimate limit of miniaturization, i.e., based on an inert, stable atomic sheet that is only a single layer thick. Within this framework, this EAGER research project intends to develop the concept of lateral continuous transitions between different single-layer materials, in which the composition of the material is controlled by chemical means to transition rapidly, e.g., from molybdenum disulfide to molybdenum diselenide. The ultimate goal is to develop a procedure by which well-defined patterns of material composition and ensuing electronic properties can be "woven" into a single atomic sheet like a pattern in a plaid cloth. If successful, this approach will provide for significantly more facile fabrication of device structures than the conventional approach. This project is conducted at a Hispanic Serving institution and directly benefits multiple Hispanic undergraduate and graduate students in the lab. It synergizes with a Research Experience for Undergraduate students site directed by the principle investigator.

Technical Description: This project intends the development of methods for the preparation of lateral compositional heterojunctions in transition metal dichalcogenide single-layer films utilizing a modified chemical vapor deposition approach. It builds on findings in the principle investigator's lab that permit the preparation of alloys between molybdenum disulfide and molybdenum diselenide at any composition. Preliminary data show that compositional gradients on the meV/micrometer scale can be fabricated. This research project investigates whether these gradients can be made sufficiently sharp and controlled so that they can set up quantum wells or other functional elements for single-layer devices. To this end, researchers apply both dedicated control of the chalcogen injection during the film growth and post-growth processing of films by sulfur-selenium exchange. Characterization proceeds primarily by optical spectroscopy augmented by electrical testing where promising results are achieved. If the project has success, the resultant structures will permit transfer of many materials and device concepts of current GaAs/GaAlAs heterojunction technology, which is the base of much of modern optoelectronics, to the world of two-dimensional films.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This EAGER project laid the foundation for the growth of single-layer transition metal dichalcogenide films with controlled lateral variation of alloy composition. Transition metal dichalcogenides are appealing materials for next-generation microelectronic applications, because their properties are fully reproducible and well-established, even if they are only a single layer thick. This sets them apart from conventional semiconducting materials, such as silicon or gallium arsenide. This project realized the growth of transition metal dichalcogenide single-layer films into patterns of different composition. Compositional variation is a common method for tuning the properties of electronic materials; it is at the heart of devices as ubiquitous as light-emitting and laser diodes. Transfer of this technique to transition metal dichalcogenide films paves the pathway for a broad range of future devices that incorporate these films.  

An important aspect of this research project was the characterization of transition metal dichalcogenide alloy films and how their electronic structure and electrical transport properties depend on composition. Dozens of devices were fabricated and characterized to achieve the latter. Film characterization proceeded in collaboration with Lawrence Livermore National Lab, so that this NSF project synergistically supported the research mission of a national lab. The electronic structure of this project was investigated by a number of lab-based techniques at the University of California, Riverside (the project location), as well as utilizing the facilities of the European Synchrotron Source (Elettra) in Trieste, Italy. The superior quality of the films prepared in this project gained us access to their coveted spectromicroscopy beamline, which is the most advanced one for work on single-layer materials in the world at this point. Numerous publications resulted from both of these collaborations.

This project was conducted at the University of California, Riverside, an accredited Hispanic Serving Institution. The graduate students working on this project were Hispanic individuals. Numerous undergraduate students, many of them Hispanic as well, had the opportunity to learn aspects of this work during their undergraduate studies. This provided them with important research experience and – for many of them – led them choose semiconductor processing as their future career goal.  This is an important contribution to Human Resource development. Integration of individuals from all backgrounds into the US high-tech sector strengthens our global competitiveness.
